# Random Experimment
A random experiment is an experiment that has a number of possible outcomes, but it is not certain which of the outcomes will occur before the experiment is performed

# Components of Probability
1. A random experiment
2. Possible outcomes (of the random experiment)
3. An event of interest

# Probability
The probability of the occurrence of event A is defined as the ratio of the number of outcomes where event A occurs to the total number of outcomes

# Probability Equation
Suppose that a random experiment may result in a number n of possible (and equally likely) outcomes, and in n(A) of these outcomes event A occurs. Then the probability of event A is defined as follows:
$Pr\{A\} = \frac{n(A)}{n}$

# Values of Probability
Probability can only take on values between zero and one i.e.
$0 \leq Pr\{A\} \leq 1$

# Sure and Impossible Event
A sure event is an event that always occurs. If I is a sure event, then

$ Pr\{I\} = 1$

An impossible event is an event that never occurs. If $\phi$ is an impossible event, then

$Pr\{\phi\} = 0$
# Complement of an Event

If $\bar{A}$ is the complement of event $A$ then the complement $\bar{A}$ only occues when event $A$ does not occur

In a random experiment with $n$ number of outcomes of which $n(A)$ os the number of outcomes in which in the event A occurs the following holds true,

$n = n(A) + n(\bar{A})$

$Pr\{A\} + Pr\{\bar{A}\} = 1$ 
or
$Pr\{\bar{A}\} = 1 - Pr\{A\}$

# Composite event (A and B)
Given two events A and B we say a composite event A and B (or AB for simplicity) occurs when both event A and event B occur

# Sure and Impossible Event
If I is a sure event then,

$Pr\{AI\} = Pr\{A\}$
If $\phi$ is an impossible event then,
$Pr\{A\phi\} = 0$

# Conditional Probability
The conditional probability of B given that A has occured is defined by:

$Pr\{B|A\} = \frac{Pr\{AB\}}{Pr\{A\}}$
Also,
$Pr\{B|A\} = \frac{n(AB)}{n(a)}$
Conditional probability $Pr\{B|A\}$ is different from the conditional probability $Pr\{A|B\}$

# Independence
Event B is said to be independent of event A if the conditional probability of B given A is equal to the (absolute) probability of B. In formula,

$Pr\{B|A\} = Pr\{B\}$
This means that the likelihood of the occurrence of B is not influenced by the occurence of A. If B is independent of A, B is also independent of $\bar{A}$ or
$Pr\{B|A\} = Pr\{B\} = Pr\{B|\bar{A}\}$

# Multiplication Theorem
The probability of AB is equal to the product of the probability of A and the conditional probability of B given A, or

$Pr\{AB\} = Pr\{A\} \times Pr\{B|A\}$ or
$Pr\{AB\} = Pr\{B\} \times Pr\{A|B\}$

$Pr\{ABC\} = Pr\{A\} \times Pr\{B|A\} \times Pr\{C|AB\}$

If the events are independent then it becomes,
$Pr\{AB\} = Pr\{A\} \times Pr\{B\}$
$Pr\{ABC\} = Pr\{A\} \times Pr\{B\} \times Pr\{C\}$

# Theorem of Pariwise Independence
If B is independent of A then A is independent of B and A and B are said to be independent events.
If, $Pr\{B|A\} = Pr\{B\}$ then $Pr\{A|B\} = Pr\{A\}$

# Composite Event (A or B)
By a composite event A or B we mean either A or B or both. Thus the event A or B occurs if either A occurs, or B occurs or AB occurs

# Mutual Exclusiveness
Two events are said to be mutually exclusive if the occurrence of one implies the non-occurence of the other; in other words they cannot occur simultaneously in a single experiment. If A and B are mutually exclusive events, then n(AB) = 0 and Pr{AB} = 0
# Addition Theorem

$Pr\{A or B\} = Pr\{A\} + Pr\{B\} - Pr\{AB\}$

When events are mutually exclusive so that $Pr\{AB=0\}$ then the the addition theorem becomes,
$Pr\{A or B\} = Pr\{A\} + Pr\{B\}$

# The distributive law
When the computation of a probability requires both the addition and multiplication theorems, the rule of the application of the two theorems is similar to that in an arithmetic problem. For eg:

$Pr\{A(B or C)\} = Pr\{AB or AC\}$
$Pr\{(A or B)(C or D)\} = Pr\{AC or AD or BC or BD\}$
